newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Three killed, seven injured in Russian train blast.
newsitem.headline: Three killed, seven injured in Russian train blast.

text.p: A bomb went off on a train between Moscow and St Petersburg on Friday, killing three people and wounding seven, an emergencies ministry official said.
"It was a bomb which was hidden in the toilets of one of the carriages," a duty officer told Reuters, He said the incident happened at around 6:30 p.m. (1430 GMT).
Another official said train number 24, heading for St Petersburg, was near Torbino station in the Novgorod region northwest of Moscow when the blast occurred.
"After a short delay, traffic on the line resumed," another emergencies ministry official said by telephone.
NTV commercial television said later that the damaged carriage had been uncoupled and the rest of the train had arrived in St Petersburg with the injured on board.
A local television reporter at the Moskovsky station in St Petersburg said by telephone that the station had been sealed off by police.
Railways Minister Nikolai Aksenenko was among officials and security police who headed for the site of the crash, NTV said.
The emergencies ministry officials said they had no indication yet as to who might have planted the bomb.
Bomb blasts are a fairly common occurrence in Russia, where explosives are often used in contract killings of businessmen.
Earlier this year, four people were killed when blasts ripped through two stations in southern Russia.
Moscow blamed those explosions on Chechen rebels, but separatist leaders in the southern republic, torn by a 21-month conflict with Russian troops which ended last August, denied any involvement.
